questions.text:
A woman brought her 14-month-old child to the PHC for routine immunization. The child was born in February 2020 at home and has not received any vaccine till now due to the lockdown. The mother is apprehensive about her child's health and wants to immunize him. Which of the following vaccines can be given to the child now?
  1. OPV
  2. Measles
  3. BCG
  4. Vitamin A
  5. Pentavalent
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 2, 4.

In the case of an unimmunized 14-month-old child, OPV, measles, and vitamin A vaccines can be given.

Catch-up vaccination involves the administration of vaccines in children who have not been immunized at all (left-outs) or for children who took vaccines but could not complete the course (dropouts).

According to the National Immunization Schedule, BCG can only be given up to 1 year of age. 

OPV can be given till 5 years of age.

Measles can be given till 5 years of age.

DPT can be given until 7 years of age (with booster doses).

Only the above-mentioned vaccines have upper age limits. 

For pentavalent, IPV, PCV, and rotavirus vaccines, if at least one dose is given before one year of age, then remaining doses can be administered and the schedule must be completed irrespective of the age of the child. If the first dose is not administered before one year of age, then these vaccines cannot be administered to the child under UIP.

questions.text: An observer notes that the maternal deaths that happened in hospital deliveries in the past year are higher than maternal deaths in home deliveries. He comes to the conclusion that homes are a safer place for delivery than hospitals. This is an example of :
questions.solution:
This is an example of spurious association. This is an association that appears due to improper comparison. It may lead to a spurious association or an association when none actually existed.

Here, maternal mortality is likely to have been higher in hospital deliveries compared to home deliveries because hospitals attract women at high risk for delivery because of their special equipment and expertise, whereas this is not necessarily the case with home deliveries. When confounding factors and selection biases are not accounted for, it may result in incorrect conclusions regarding the association. So the conclusion that homes are a safer place for delivery than hospitals is likely to have been spurious or artifactual.

Association can be broadly grouped under three headings:

  • Spurious association
  • Indirect association
  • Direct (causal) association
    • One-to-one causal association
    • Multifactorial causation

Option A: Direct (causal) association- Two variables are stated to be causally related (AB) if a change in A is followed by a change in B. When factor A is present, disease B must result. Measles is one such disease in which such a relation exists.

Option B: Indirect association- The indirect association is an association between a  variable and disease due to the presence of another factor, known or unknown, that is also known as the "confounding" variable. For example, endemic goiter is generally found in high altitudes, showing thereby an association between altitude and endemic goiter. But, endemic goiter is not due to altitude but due to environmental deficiency of iodine. Thus, a common factor (i.e., iodine deficiency) can result in an apparent association between two variables, when no association exists. 

Option D: Multifactorial causation is seen in non-communicable diseases or conditions (e.g., Coronary heart disease) where the etiology is multifactorial.

questions.text: You are a medical officer at the PHC. During the training, the PHC nursing staff asks you about the DPT vaccination. While explaining the same, you mention that the 'open vial policy' is applicable to the DPT vaccine. What do you want to convey by this term?

choices.text: Once the vial is opened, it should be discarded even if it is not used completely.
Once the vial is opened, it can be reused upto 4 weeks subject to certain conditions.
Once the vial is opened, It can be reused upto 48 hours subject to certain conditions.
Once the vial is opened, it should be kept open until it is completely used.

questions.solution:
Open vial policy means once the vial is opened, it can be reused for upto 4 weeks subject to certain conditions.

It is not applicable for BCG, JE, and measles vaccines.

It is applicable for:

  • DPT
  • TT
  • Hepatitis B vaccine
  • OPV
  • Pentavalent vaccine
  • Rotavirus vaccine
  • Japanese encephalitis vaccine (inactivated)

Note: Open vial policy does not apply to rotavirus vaccine with VVM on cap, it applies only to new rotavirus vaccine with VVM on label.

Related Pearl: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

questions.text: Meta-analysis is mainly influenced by which of the following biases?
questions.solution:
Meta-analysis is mainly influenced by publication bias.

Meta-analysis is the quantitative analysis of the results of a systematic review; its validity depends on the quality of the review and the underlying studies.

Publication bias occurs when studies with significant results are more likely to be published than non-significant results, misleading about the actual studies. The extent to which meta-analysis is influenced by publication bias is often assessed using:  

  • Selection model: Selection models use weight functions to adjust the overall effect size estimate and are usually employed as sensitivity analyses to assess the potential impact of publication bias.  
  • Funnel plot: It displays the effect size against the sample size. Normally, variability in the results will be more for smaller studies than for larger studies. So, in a funnel plot for small studies, we get an inverted funnel with more results varying from the mean. Whereas in larger studies, results cluster around the overall mean effect due to less variability. If the small studies are producing less precise results than larger studies, their results should be symmetrically spread around the mean giving rise to an inverted funnel-shaped plot. 

If this is not the case, and the results of smaller studies are distributed asymmetrically. This indicates that some unfavorable results from the study are missing due to various biases.  

Option A: Selection bias – a sampling bias, non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population. 

Option B: Attribution bias – participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. 

Option C: Recall bias – an objective bias, the differential ability of cases and control to recall a certain detail. 

Related Pearl: Meta-analysis in Research

  • Meta-analysis is a set of statistical techniques for combining quantitative results from multiple studies to produce a summary of empirical knowledge on a given topic.
  • It refers to a method of systematic review.
  • It is one of the most relevant methods in evidence-based medicine and ranks high on the evidence pyramid.
  • Limitations
    • When testing is done before hypothesis generation, spurious results are found.
    • Sample size may be misrepresentative.
    • Publication bias due to suppression of some important information leading to file drawer effect.
    • Heterogeneity of studies may force mashing together of disparate effects and lead to selection bias. This is also called apples and oranges effect.
    • Dissimilarities in control groups.
    • Its validity is dependent on the quality of the systematic review and the original data used.

Related Pearl: Funnel Plots

  • A funnel plot is basically a scatter plot of individual studies which are used in systematic reviews and meta-analysis. It plots their precisions and results.
  • In a funnel plot, each dot represents an individual study.
  • The y-axis is usually the standard error or another estimate of precision and the x-axis is the outcome, usually the odds ratio.
  • Higher powered studies are placed towards the top and the lower powered ones towards the bottom such that the plot resembles an inverted funnel or a pyramid.

questions.text: Diseases in which clinical recovery does not coincide with bacteriological recovery give rise to which kind of carrier?
questions.solution:
Diseases in which clinical recovery does not coincide with bacteriological recovery give rise to the convalescent carrier.

In cases of typhoid fever, dysentery (bacillary and amebic), cholera, diphtheria, and whooping cough, patients continue to shed the disease agent during the period of recovery following an illness (convalescence). They pose a serious threat to unprotected household members and those in the immediate environment.

Other options:

Option A: Paradoxical carriers are carriers who acquired the pathogen from another carrier. Example: A carrier with subclinical polio infection acquired the pathogen from another household member, who is also a carrier for poliovirus.

Option B: Incubatory carriers are those who shed infectious agents during the incubation period and can carriers transmit the disease before the onset of symptoms. Examples: measles, mumps, polio, pertussis, influenza, diphtheria, and hepatitis B.

Option D: Healthy carriers acquire the infectious agent but do not develop any symptoms of disease and keep shedding the agent. Examples: Poliomyelitis, cholera, meningococcal meningitis, salmonellosis, and diphtheria.

questions.text: A study shows a relationship between Oral cancer and the consumption of alcohol, with a relative risk of 1.9 and a p-value of <0.01. The study subjects are then divided into two groups: beetle nut chewers and non-beetle nut chewers. The association between Oral cancer and the consumption of alcohol is studied again, which yields an RR value of 0.87 and P value >0.05. Which of the following is the reason behind the difference between the initial RR and P value and the stratified RR and P value?
questions.solution:
Confounding bias is the reason behind the difference between the initial RR and P value and the stratified RR and P value.

Initial analysis (before stratification) suggests that there is an association between oral cancer and the consumption of alcohol, with a relative risk of 1.9 and a p-value < 0.05 ( statistically significant). Beetle nut chewing is associated with both oral carcinoma and alcohol consumption (Generally, people who consume tobacco most likely consume alcohol as well). Hence, beetle nut chewing is a potential confounder that may explain the association observed between oral cancer and alcohol consumption. Stratified analysis by beetle nut chewing status shows that both beetle nut chewers and non-chewers have an RR < 1 with p-values (>0.05)(statistically insignificant). The RR of 1.9 found on initial analysis disappears, and there is no true association between oral cancer and alcohol consumption.

This is an example of confounding bias. Beetle nut chewing is the confounding factor.

A confounding factor is defined as one that is associated with both exposure and outcome and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. In this study to determine the role of beer in the etiology of oral cancer, beetle nut chewing is considered a confounding factor because:

  • It is associated with the consumption of alcohol (exposure).
  • It is an independent risk factor for oral cancer (outcome).

Methods to reduce confounding:

  • At the time of designing the study:  
    • Randomization
    • Matching
    • Restriction
  • At the time of analysis:
    • Stratification
    • Statistical modelling like regression analysis, multivariate analysis and the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel method.

Other options:

Option A: Stratified randomization, which is also known as pre-stratification or blocking, is a technique to eliminate confounding bias. It is a process that combines both randomization and matching techniques. In this method, the participants are first grouped into subgroups that internally match with potential confounding factors such as age, race, gender, etc. An equal number of participants from each subgroup are then allocated to the study and control groups.

Option C: Selection bias is a type of sampling bias that occurs because of the nonrandom allocation of subjects such that the study population is not representative of the target population. The best way to reduce this is by randomization to create groups with similar distributions of known and unknown variables. 

Option D: Neyman’s or prevalence-incidence bias occurs in case-control studies when exposure affects both the disease and the disease-induced mortality.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text:
Which of the following are methods of indirect transmission of communicable diseases?
  1. Contact with soil
  2. Droplet nuclei
  3. Fomite borne
  4. Unclean hands and fingers
  5. Transplacental
questions.solution:
Among the given options, droplet nuclei, fomite borne and transmission through unclean hands and fingers are modes of indirect transmission of diseases.

Communicable diseases are classified based on the mode of transmission:

  • Direct:
    • Direct contact (Eg: sexual intercourse)
    • Contact with soil
    • Droplet infection
    • Skin or mucosal inoculation
    • Transplacental 
  • Indirect: 
    • Vehicle-borne
    • Vector-borne
    • Air-borne
      • Droplet nuclei
      • Dust
    • Fomite-borne
    • Unclean hands and fingers

The traditional 5 F's - flies, fingers, fomites, food, and fluids can be used to remember the modes of indirect transmission. Some infectious agents are able to survive in the external environment while maintaining their basic properties of virulence. This is a  requirement for this indirect transmission. 

An important distinction has to be drawn between droplet nuclei infection and droplet infection. The main difference between airborne droplet nuclei and droplet transmission is in the size of infected/contagious particles and whether proximity is required for transmission.

Droplet nuclei/residue from evaporated droplets containing infective microorganisms can result in airborne transmission. The size of these droplet nuclei is <5 μm in diameter, and they can remain suspended in the air for significant periods of time, allowing them to be transmitted over distances >1 m.  There's no need for close proximity or contact. Diseases like chickenpox, measles, tuberculosis, and influenza can spread through airborne transmission.

Droplet transmission occurs when one coughs or sneezes, and contagious droplets from the infected person travel shortly in the air and directly comes in contact with another person's conjunctiva, mouth, or nasal mucosa. The particle size here is >5 μm in diameter. Transmission here requires close proximity and direct contact. Examples of diseases spread via this route include the common cold, diphtheria, and whooping cough.

questions.text: A patient with a category-II dog bite presents to the trauma center on 2nd June 2023. After the local wound management, the patient has been prescribed a schedule for rabies vaccine administration. He marks the days in a calendar as shown below when he is supposed to take the vaccine.  Which regimen is likely prescribed to the patient? What is the route of administration in this case?

choices.text: Updated Thai Red Cross regimen, intramuscular
Updated Thai Red Cross regimen, intradermal

questions.solution:
The regimen prescribed here is the Updated Thai red cross regimen which is intradermal.

The National Rabies Control Program recommends the use of the intradermal route for administering the rabies vaccine.

The Updated Thai Red Cross regimen (Intra-dermal) involves injecting 0.1 ml of reconstituted vaccine per ID site and on two sites on days 0, 3, 7, and 28. (2-2-2-0-2). The first dose is given on day 0. It's important to note that the intradermal route is not recommended for individuals with compromised immune systems.

On the other hand, the Essen regimen (Intra-muscular) involves injecting either 1 ml or 0.5 ml of vaccine into the deltoid muscle. It consists of a 5-dose regimen, with one dose given on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28. (1,1,1,1,1)

The following measures should be taken immediately to stop the contraction of rabies:

  • Cleansing - The most important step in the prevention of rabies is washing the affected area with plenty of soap and water under a running tap for 15 minutes. This is a standard procedure that minimizes the contraction of rabies.
  • Chemical treatment - Irrigation of the wound should then be done with virucidal agents like alcohol, tincture, 0.01% solution of aqueous iodine, or povidone-iodine. Even irrigating the wound with cetrimide + chlorhexidine solution can be done. This process eliminates the residual virus in the wound.
  • Suturing - Bite wounds are not sutured generally. If suturing is necessary, it is done after 24-48 hours under the cover of local infiltration of the rabies immunoglobulin which is generally done in category III wounds.
  • Other measures - Local antibiotics and tetanus toxoids should be given.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: Which is not included in the 4-pronged strategy for PPTCT (Prevention of Parent to Child Transmission of HIV )?

choices.text: Prevention of unintended pregnancies among women living with HIV
Initiating pre-exposure prophylaxis in female sex workers
Primary prevention of HIV among women of childbearing age
Provide care, support, and treatment to women and their families living with HIV

questions.solution:
Initiating pre-exposure prophylaxis in female sex workers is not included in the 4-pronged strategy for PPTCT.

The National PPTCT programme identifies four elements in preventing HIV transmission among women and children. These include the following: 

Prong 1: Primary prevention of HIV (Option C), especially among women of childbearing age - This can be achieved by the implementation of the general population-based HIV prevention strategy and the Adolescent Reproductive and Sexual Health (ARSH) programme. 

Prong 2: Prevention of unintended pregnancies (Option A) among women living with HIV -This strategy aims at educating all HIV-positive women on available options of contraception and family planning methods. HIV-positive women should be assisted in making decisions regarding planning a pregnancy and childbirth by the staff of ICTC, ART centre and CSC. 

Prong 3: Prevention of HIV transmission from pregnant women infected with HIV to their children - This includes linking HIV-positive pregnant mothers to ART centres for ART initiation, counselling for adherence to ART and safe sex practices, referral for plasma viral load between 32 and 36 weeks of pregnancy to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby and decision on the type of infant ARV prophylaxis. Institutional deliveries and ARV prophylaxis to their babies with infant feeding counselling 

Prong 4: Provide care, support and treatment (Option D) to women living with HIV and to their children and families - This includes treatment support, feeding counselling, immunisation, and linking their children to the PPTCT centre for the care of HIV-exposed infants, including the EID programme.

Important provisions of PPTCT services for HIV:

  • HIV counseling and testing for all pregnant women enrolled in antenatal care with ‘opt out’ option.
  • Lifelong ART i.e. Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine (3TC)+ Dolutegravir (DTG) administration to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women regardless of CD4 count and clinical stage.
  • Institutional deliveries of HIV-infected mothers
  • Care of associated conditions (STI/RTI, TB, opportunistic infections, hypertension, diabetes)
  • Exclusive breastfeeding counseling
  • Plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby
  • Initiation of ARV in babies:
    • Low-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine from birth till 6 weeks of age
    • High-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine+ syrup Zidovudine either from birth till 6 weeks of age (exclusive replacement feeding) or from birth till 12 weeks of age (exclusive breastfeeding)
  • Nutrition counseling and psychosocial support to HIV-infected pregnant women
  • Ensure co-trimoxazole prophylactic therapy (CPT) and early infant diagnosis using HIV-DNA PCR at 6 weeks of age onwards as per guidelines

questions.text: You are the medical officer of a community health center and asked to find out the incidence rate of a disease in your community. Which of the following information cannot be derived from the incidence rate?

choices.text: Magnitude of disease in the community

questions.solution:
The magnitude of disease in the community cannot be assessed from the incidence rate.

The incidence rate is defined as the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a specified period of time. The incidence rate must be described in units of time. It is given by the formula:

Incidence = (Number of new cases of specific disease during a given time period / Population at risk in that period) x 1000.

Incidence measures the rate at which new cases are occurring in a population. The duration of a disease does not affect its incidence. The incidence is generally calculated in acute conditions. Uses of incidence rates as a health status indicator:

  • Incidence can indicate the possible etiology of a disease. For example, a common infectious source would lead to a peak in the incidence of a disease.
  • By studying the pattern of incidence of a disease, we can formulate measures to control the disease outbreak.
  • A decrease in the incidence of a disease would reflect on the efficacy of a therapeutic measure taken to cure that disease.
  • The distribution of disease can be determined by studying incidence with respect to age, geography, gender, socioeconomic standards, etc.

The specialized incidence rates are:

  • Attack rate - It is an incidence rate expressed in percentage. It is used when the population is exposed to a risk factor for a short amount of time as in epidemics.  It reflects the number of new cases in the at-risk population due to the risk factor. 
  • Secondary attack rate - It is defined as the number of cases that develop following exposure to the primary case within one incubation period.

The magnitude of disease or health problems in the community is given by prevalence. It is also useful in identifying potential high-risk populations. Prevalence refers specifically to all current cases (old and new) existing at a given point in time, or over a period of time in a given population. Prevalence rates are useful for administrative and planning purposes like manpower needs, hospital beds needed, etc.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

Related Pearl: Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

questions.text: Which of the following describes correctly the route and dosage of the killed Japanese encephalitis vaccine under the National Immunization Schedule?
questions.solution:
Under the National Immunization Schedule (NIS), administration of 0.5ml of killed JE vaccine is via the intramuscular route.

The Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus is transmitted by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species. They present with fever and headache in mild disease form and severe disease presents with rapid onset of high fever, headache, neck stiffness, disorientation, coma, seizures, spastic paralysis, and ultimately death.

Killed JE vaccines (Inactivated SA 14-14-2 cell culture-derived and inactivated Vero cell culture-derived) are gradually replacing live attenuated vaccines. This change is because the killed vaccines are reported to have better immunogenicity than the live attenuated vaccine.

The SA 14-14-2 (live attenuated) vaccine is based on a stable neuro-attenuated strain of the JE virus with a Yellow Fever vaccine acting as a viral vector. Adverse effects of the vaccine include fever and rash.

The dosage of the vaccine is 0.5ml and the site of administration is as follows:

  • Live vaccine: Subcutaneous, left upper arm
  • Killed vaccine: Intramuscular, anterolateral side of left mid-thigh

They can be administered to up to 15 years of age with a month gap between the two doses.

The JE virus vaccine has been included in the National Immunization Schedule (NIS) to be administered in endemic areas (Uttar Pradesh, Assam, West Bengal, Karnataka) in two doses. The first dose is administered at 9-12 completed months. The second dose is administered at 16-24 months. The schedule however mentions the use of both live and killed vaccines.

questions.text: You were posted for screening of deafness in school children under your primary health center. Which type of screening is done in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The type of screening done for deafness in school children is prescriptive screening. 

Prescriptive screening is done for case detection. People are examined primarily for their own benefit. It may lead to the early identification of an unrecognized disease. Hence, appropriate treatment can be initiated immediately to decline the disease progression.

Screening is initiated by medical and public health personnel and is not requested by a patient. Examples of prescriptive screening are:

  • Screening of hemolytic disease in newborns
  • Screening of infants for phenylketonuria
  • Screening of bacteriuria in pregnancy
  • Screening of school children for visual and auditory defects

Other options:

Option A - Prospective screening is done for disease control. People are screened for the benefit of others. It may lead to an early diagnosis and permit more effective treatment. It also reduces the spread of infectious diseases in the community. Hence, reduces mortality associated with the disease. Examples of prospective screening are:

  • Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and syphilis to protect the citizens
  • Screening for streptococcal infection to prevent rheumatic fever
  • Screening of sex workers for HIV to prevent transmission of HIV to others
  • Screening of COVID infection among the international passengers at the airport

Option B - Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination, to a large population at one time. It is not cost-effective and has shown no benefit in reducing the morbidity and mortality of the population.

Option D - Selective screening is done in high-risk groups. It is one of the most effective screening tests. Example: Screening for diabetes in the other members of a family for a detected diabetes case since these diseases get aggregated in families.

3. Secondary c. Educating children about the harmful effects of smoking.

questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b.

1. Primordial C. Educating children about the harmful effects of smoking.
2. Primary D. Use of helmets and eye protection in factories.
3. Secondary A. Screening children from economically weaker families for malnutrition.
4. Tertiary B. Reconstructive surgery for patients with residual deformities due to leprosy.

Primordial prevention prevents the emergence of risk factors themselves. The interventions revolve around trying to encourage children to adopt healthy lifestyles to prevent health issues in adulthood. Thus, educating children about the harmful effects of smoking is an example of primordial prevention. 

The use of helmets and eye protection in factories is an example of specific protection against industrial hazards. While the risk factors have emerged (working around dangerous machinery), the intervention is to prevent any injury. Thus, it comes under primary prevention. 

Screening children from economically weaker families is an example of early diagnosis. This intervention identifies the children who have malnutrition as soon as possible, to begin treatment. Thus, it comes under secondary prevention.

Reconstruction surgery for leprosy patients is an intervention to rehabilitate patients and bring some extent of physical function back. It comes under disability limitation and rehabilitation, and thus, is a tertiary level of prevention.

questions.text:
In a study that investigates the relationship between steroid contraceptives and breast cancer, there is found to be a strong association between age and breast cancer, resulting in a confounding bias. Which of the following is an approach to eliminate such an association?
  1. Restriction
  2. Randomization
  3. Blinding
  4. Pre-Stratification
  5. Deletion
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 2, 4.
 
In the given study age is found to be a confounding factor. Confounding bias in the given study with age as a confounding factor can be eliminated by restriction, randomization, and pre-stratification. 
 
A confounding factor is defined as one associated with both exposure and disease and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. In the given example, if the study is conducted without eliminating the confounding factor, there is an unexpectedly strong association between the confounding factor (e.g.. age) and the disease (e.g., breast cancer)

 Techniques to eliminate confounding factors include:
  • Randomization
  • Matching
  • Stratified randomization
  • Restriction
Randomization is the random allocation of the participants in experimental studies (Randomized control trials) into the study group and control group.

Matching, which is usually done in analytical studies (for example, case-control and cohort studies), is the process where the participants in two groups are matched based on factors such as age, gender, race, smoking status, etc. to eliminate the potential confounders.
 
Stratified randomization, which is also known as pre-stratification or blocking, is the process that combines both randomization and matching techniques. In this method, the participants are first grouped into subgroups that internally match with potential confounding factors such as age, race, gender, etc. An equal number of participants from each subgroup are then allocated to the study and control groups.
 
Restriction: This method restricts the study to only those participants with particular characteristics. For example, a study can be restricted to participants of only one gender, race, age group, geographical area, disease severity, etc., thus eliminating the potential confounders.
 
Other options:
 
Blinding and deletion do not eliminate confounding factors. Blinding is done to eliminate other biases such as subject bias, observer bias, or investigator bias.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: A new genetic syndrome has been defined, and its etiology is being debated by many scholars all around the world. A study is being performed, where you will describe the disease according to its distribution in terms of time, place and person, to formulate the hypothesis. In this study, you will do____.
questions.solution:
A descriptive study is the study of choice for formulating an etiological hypothesis of a disease, where only observation is done.

Types of epidemiological study:

  1. Observational study
    • Descriptive studies (hypothesis formulation)
    • Analytical studies (hypothesis testing)

     2. Experimental studies/Intervention study (hypothesis confirmation)

A descriptive study is undertaken to formulate an etiological hypothesis for a given disease. On the other hand, an analytical study is performed to test the hypothesis (i.e. to accept or reject the hypothesis).

questions.text: Results of various studies carried out to study the role of smoking in breast cancer are plotted below. Which of these studies are statistically insignificant?
questions.solution:
The image shown is that of a forest plot used for plotting the results of a meta-analysis. Any study whose confidence intervals touch the "line of no effect" is considered statistically insignificant. In this given plot Studies A, B, and C are touching the line of no effect and hence are statistically insignificant.

A forest plot/blobbogram is used to present the results of a meta-analysis. It allows the results to be seen at a glance, with ready identification of outliers. Each study is represented as a rectangle and a horizontal line. The size of the rectangle represents the sample size of the study. The horizontal line on either side of the result shows the 95% confidence interval surrounding the point estimate.

The vertical solid line is the “line of no effect,” where there is no difference between having the risk factor and the absence of the risk factor. (i.e., a risk ratio of zero). If any study touches this line such a study is statistically insignificant.

In other words, when the confidence intervals of a study include an Odds Ratio of 1.0, that study is statistically insignificant. A forest plot also compares individual studies, for deciding whether a drug is significantly better than a placebo or not.

Related Pearl: Forest Plot

  • A forest plot is used to present the results of a meta-analysis.
  • It is also called blobbogram.

Interpretation of forest plots: 

  • The rectangles represent the single studies
  • The size of the rectangle is proportional to the sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side - confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
  • The vertical solid line - the “line of no effect", which represents the odds ratio or relative risk. If it is the odds ratio, then the vertical line would be at 1. No difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1). 
  • The location of the result - whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not
  • A diamond shows the overall pooled result where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
  • The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analysed measure of effect.

Let's understand with an example - 

  • For study A- it has a wide horizontal line that crosses the line of null effect with a black box that is to the right of the vertical line. This most likely demonstrates a small scale study with few participants where the point estimate result favours the control used in the study. But because the study contains the null value in its 95% confidence interval, it is likely to have a p-value >0.05 and not be statistically significant.
  • For study B- it has quite a narrow line that does not cross the line of null effect with a black box that is to the left of the vertical line and is bigger than study A. This most likely demonstrates a larger study with more participants compared to study A, where the result favours the intervention used. Because the 95% confidence interval does not contain the null value, this study is likely to have a p-value <0.05 and hence the differences observed in the study can be regarded as statistically significant.

questions.text: An epidemiologist gives a lecture on pandemics. He gives influenza pandemics as an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Influenza pandemics are an example of a cyclical trend.

A cyclical trend is a type of periodic fluctuation. It occurs in cycles that are spread over short periods of time. This can be days, weeks, months, or even years.  Examples of the cyclic trend include influenza and rubella. Some non-infectious conditions can also display cyclical trends. An example of this is road traffic accidents occurring more frequently on the weekends. Knowledge of the cyclical pattern of diseases can be used to defend communities against the same.

Other options:

Option A: Seasonal trend is another type of period fluctuation which refers to seasonal variation of diseases. Examples of diseases that follow this trend include measles, malaria, and upper respiratory tract infections. It can be related to environmental conditions such as temperature and humidity. Some non-infectious conditions which follow this trend are sunstroke, hay fever, and snakebite. Some epidemiologists consider this a form of cyclic trend.

Option B: Secular or long-term trend signifies the changes seen in the occurrence of a disease over a long period of time. It implies a consistent change in a particular direction such as a progressive increase or decrease. Examples of conditions that follow this pattern are coronary heart disease and lung cancer which have shown a consistent upward trend. A decline in the occurrence of diseases such as tuberculosis and diphtheria has been noted in developed countries. 

Option C: Point-source epidemic is a type of common-source epidemic. In this type of epidemic, there are no secondary waves and the epidemic curve rises and falls rapidly. There is a clustering of cases within a narrow interval of time. All the cases develop within one incubation period of the specific disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the steps of acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) surveillance?

choices.text: Fecal samples should arrive at the lab within 48 hours of collection
All children with AFP should be tested within 72 hours of onset
Should be able to detect atleast 1 case of AFP/100000 children under 15 years
Fecal specimens should be transported at 2°C

questions.solution:
The statement "Detect at least 1 case of AFP/100000 children under 15 years" is true with regard to the steps of AFP surveillance.

There are four steps under AFP surveillance:

  1.  Finding and reporting children with AFP: 
    • The staff in all health facilities should report every case of AFP in any child less than 15 years of age.
    • The surveillance system of the country should be able to detect at least one case of AFP for every 1,00,000 children under 15 years of age, even in the absence of polio.
  1. Transporting stool samples for analysis:
    • All children with AFP should be reported and tested for wild poliovirus within 48 hours of onset. (option B)
    • The faecal samples are used to test for polio. The specimens should be collected within the first two weeks after the onset of paralysis since the highest concentration of the poliovirus is found during this period.
    • Stool specimens have to be sealed in containers and stored immediately inside a refrigerator or packed between frozen ice packs at 4–8 degrees Celsius in a cold box (option D). Specimens should arrive at the laboratory within 72 hours of collection (option A). Otherwise, they must be frozen at –20 degrees Celsius and then shipped frozen. The procedure is known as the “reverse cold chain”.
  1. Isolating poliovirus:
    • Isolation of the virus followed by distinguishing between wild and vaccine-related poliovirus.
    • If the wild type is isolated, then the virologists identify which of the two surviving types is involved.
  1. Mapping the virus:
    • If the wild type of virus is found, the genetic makeup of the virus is further studied and is compared with the reference bank of known polioviruses to know about the geographical origin of the virus.
    • Once the geographical area is identified, the source of the importation virus can be known. Immunization strategies can be determined accordingly. 

The differential diagnosis for acute flaccid paralysis includes:

  • Non-polio enteroviruses
  • West Nile virus
  • Guillan–Barre syndrome
  • Other neurotropic viruses: rabies, varicella-zoster, and Japanese encephalitis.

questions.solution:
The spleen rate is used for measuring the endemicity of malaria in a community.

The spleen rate refers to the percentage of children aged 2 to 10 years showing an enlarged spleen. Surveys focusing on spleen enlargement exclude adults since various factors other than malaria can cause splenic enlargement in this population. The spleen rate is a commonly employed measure measuring the endemicity of malaria in a community.

The slide positivity rate represents the proportion of slides that test positive for the presence of malarial parasites, regardless of the specific species. It provides information on the trend of malaria transmission.

The annual blood examination rate is the percentage of the number of slides examined in a population. It is an index of operational efficiency.

The annual parasitic incidence (API) is a method of assessing the incidence of malaria within a community. It involves comprehensive active and passive surveillance, with confirmed cases determined through blood examinations. In India, regions with an API≥2 per 1000 population per year are categorized as high-risk areas, making them eligible for targeted vector control measures.

questions.text:
You are a supervising officer doing a quality check of vaccine storage at a PHC. You need not perform a shake test on which of the following vaccines?
  1. MMR vaccine
  2. DPT vaccine
  3. Hepatitis B vaccine
  4. OPV
  5. Rabies vaccine
questions.solution:
MMR (Measles, mumps, rubella), OPV (Oral poliovirus vaccine), and rabies vaccines are not damaged by freezing. Hence shake test is not required for these vaccines.

The shake test is used to check if the freeze-sensitive vaccines have been damaged by exposure to temperatures below 0°C. Once it has been thawed, the vial of freeze-damage vaccine no longer has the appearance of a cloudy liquid but tends to form flakes that settle down at the bottom of the vial.

Steps to perform the shake test:

  • A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial, and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.
  • Both are shaken after thawing, and the rate of sedimentation is compared.
  • If the rate of sedimentation in the test vial is slower than that in the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.

Some of the most widely used vaccines are freeze sensitive:

  • Hepatitis B
  • Pentavalent
  • IPV (Inactivated poliovirus)
  • DPT 
  • TT
  • PCV

Vaccines like BCG, Japanese encephalitis(live and inactivated), MMR, OPV, Rabies, and Varicella-zoster virus vaccines do not lose their potency and efficacy on freezing. Hence, these vaccines can be used again once they liquefy.

questions.text:
Data obtained from an RCT testing a new hypolipidemic drug is given below. How many patients need to be treated to prevent one death?
  Placebo group Hypolipidemic drug group
Number of patients who died due to cardiovascular causes 145 20
Total number of patients in each group 1250 1250
questions.solution:
10 patients need to be treated with the new hypolipidemic drug to prevent 1 death.
 
The number needed to treat (NNT) is defined as the number of individuals that need to be treated with the new drug to prevent 1 death (or to save 1 life).
 
NNT = 1/ARR or 100/ARR, if the absolute risk reduction is already in percentage.
 
Here, ARR is the absolute risk reduction. ARR is the difference in the incidence between the placebo and the drug group. This formula is the same as that for attributable risk. Note that in clinical epidemiology, absolute risk reduction/increase is used identically to attributable risk.
 
Calculation:

ARR = Incidence in the placebo group — Incidence in the drug group
ARR = 145/1250  — 20/1250
ARR = 125/1250 = 1/10
 
NNT = 1/ARR = 10
 
Thus, 10 patients need to be treated with the new hypolipidemic drug to prevent one death due to cardiovascular causes.

questions.text: As a medical officer, you have to calculate the secondary attack rate of an unknown respiratory infection in your village. Considering the incubation period of the disease to be one week, which of the following would you include in the denominator?

choices.text: Total number of close contacts both immunized and non-immunized
Total number of susceptible people along with the primary case
Total number of susceptible close contacts
Total number of close contacts developing the disease within 1 week

questions.solution:
Total number of susceptible close contacts is a part of the denominator of the secondary attack rate.

The secondary attack rate is defined as the probability that disease occurs among susceptible persons, following exposure to an infectious person within the range of the incubation period.

Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed or susceptible persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100)/ (Total number of susceptible close contacts).

The secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease. The ones who are dead/ immunized/ not susceptible/ primary cases are excluded from the denominator.

questions.text:
All the following indices are useful for the measurement of disability except?

PQLI - Physical Quality of Life Index
DALY - Disability Adjusted Life Years
questions.solution:
PQLI includes infant mortality rate, literacy, and life expectancy at 1 year whereas other indicators are directly related to the measurement of disability.

Disability rates include the following:

Sullivan's index is also known as disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) or active life expectancy. It is the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability if the current patterns of mortality and disability continue to apply. It doesn’t take into account premature death. (Option A and B)
Disability-free life expectancy = (Life expectancy) - (the duration of the disability).

DALY is the best measure of the overall disease burden in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions. It can measure both mortality and disability together. (Option D)
DALY = Years of lost life (YLL) + Years lost of disability (YLD)

HALE (Health Adjusted Life Expectancy) is an indicator that can be used to estimate the number of years a newborn is expected to live in full health based on the current rates of ill health and mortality. HALE is calculated using the life expectancy at birth with an adjustment for time spent in poor health. It captures both fatal and non-fatal health outcomes of average levels of population health. It is also sensitive to changes over time or differences between countries in the distribution of health states.

QALY (Quality-adjusted life years) is used to assess disease burden by considering both the quality and length of life. It helps evaluate the cost-effectiveness of medical treatments, based on the number of additional years of life the intervention can provide, adjusted for quality.

questions.text: A PSM intern surveying a rural hostel notices multiple rat infestations on the premises. Anticipating ill health effects, he calculated the cheopsis index and found it to be more than 1. What is the inference gained from his observation?

choices.text: There is a high prevalence of plague among the inhabitants
There is a high likelihood of plague outbreak
It indicates a high prevalence of diseased rats
It indicates a low potential of disease spread from the rodent

questions.solution:
Cheopis index among the flea indices indicates that there is a high likelihood of an outbreak.

It is the best determinant of potential plague outbreaks.It is the measure of the average number of Xenopsylla cheopis per rat.  If this index is > 1, it indicates that there is a high likelihood of a plague outbreak. 

A plague is a zoonotic infection caused by Yersinia pestis and is usually transmitted by the bite of an infected rat flea. Rodent burrows serve as a favorable surface for the bacteria to grow and thus get transmitted by rat fleas. The most common vector that effectively spreads the infection is Xenopsylla cheopis. Flea indices are used to assess the density of the vector. 

Related Pearl: Flea Indices

They are useful in measurements of density of fleas.

They include: 

  • Total flea index – it is the average number of fleas of all species per rat
  • Cheopis index - it is the average number of Xenopsylla cheopis species per rat,hence it is a specific flea index. It indicates the maximum explosiveness of the situation
  • Specific percentage of fleas – it is a precentage of different species of fleas that are found on rats.
  • Burrow index – It is the average  number of free living flea per species per rodent burrow.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: The incidence rate of lung cancer is 120/100,000 person-years for smokers and 10/100,000 person-years for nonsmokers. The prevalence of smoking is 20% in the community. If the prevalence of smoking in the community was decreased to 10%, the excess incidence rate of lung cancer that could be averted in that community would be?
questions.solution:
If the prevalence of smoking was reduced to 10%, 11/100,000 excess cases of lung cancer due to smoking could be averted.

We can calculate this by using the population attributable risk (PAR) = (attributable risk) x (prevalence of exposure in the population).

The relative risk is defined as the incidence rate among the exposed (Ie) divided by the incidence rate among the nonexposed (Io).
In this case, (120/100,000)/(10/100,000) = 12.

The attributable risk (AR) is defined as Ie − Io = (120/100,000) − (10/100,000) = 110/100,000.
The attributable risk percentage is equal to [(Ie − Io) / Ie] × 100 = (110/100,000)/(120/100,000) = 92%.

If the prevalence of smoking in the population is 20%, then the PAR is calculated as follows:

    AR × prevalence of exposure = 110/100,00 × 20/100 = 22/100,000.

If the prevalence of smoking is 10%, then

    AR × prevalence of exposure = 110/100,000 × 10/100 = 11/100,000.

Therefore, excess incidence rate of lung cancer that can be avoided is (22/100,000) - (11/100,000) = (11/100,000)

questions.text: You are an intern in the paediatrics outpatient department. An overweight child, suspected of obesity is brought for assessment of body fat. questions.solution:
The mid-thigh region is not commonly measured for skinfold thickness.

  3. Subscapular region

questions.text: You are a physician at a primary health center. A 2-year-old child weighing 12 kg is brought to you. He appears lethargic and is not taking food or fluids orally. On examination, he has a respiratory rate of 45/min, and stridor is heard. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Give a dose of IV chloramphenicol and urgently refer to the hospital

questions.solution:
The child in this case has features of severe pneumonia with the presence of danger signs like lethargy, inability to drink, and stridor. Therefore, pre-referral treatment like the first dose of injectable chloramphenicol should be given and urgently referred to a hospital. If chloramphenicol is not available, oral amoxicillin can be given.

This is based on the revised WHO classification and treatment of childhood pneumonia at health facilities. questions.text: During rural postings at a CHC, you noticed a relative rise in dengue cases recently and would like to take measures to control the mosquitoes. Which among the following is not an anti-adult measure?
questions.solution:
Chlorpyrifos is not an anti-adult measure in controlling mosquitoes.

DDT, malathion, and pyrethrum are anti-adult measures, whereas chlorpyrifos is an anti-larval.

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

questions.text: A physician uses the following instrument to measure temperature in one of his patients and he wants to disinfect it before using it on another patient. It can be best disinfected by _______
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a clinical thermometer, and it is best disinfected using Savlon.

Savlon is a quaternary ammonia compound (QAC) that contains Cetavlon (cetrimide) and Hibitane (chlorhexidine). Plastic items can be disinfected by keeping them in normal strength Savlon for 20 minutes. Clinical thermometers can be disinfected in savlon in just under 3 minutes.

Other options: 

Option A - Cresol is a coal-tar disinfectant that is best used in 5-10% strength for disinfection of feces and urine.

Option B - Chloroxylenol (Dettol) is an antiseptic that is active against streptococci. A 5% solution is suitable for disinfection of instruments and plastic equipment, with minimum contact of 15 minutes required for disinfection.

Option D - Lysol is a "saponified cresol" where cresol is emulsified with soap. It contains 50- 60 percent cresol and is a powerful disinfectant. A 2 percent solution of Lysol may be used for the disinfection of feces.
